sn35.69:1.1: The commentary says this was Upasena son of Vaṅgantā, Sāriputta’s younger brother. When newly ordained, he made the mistake of ordaining students too early (Kd 1:31.3.2), but later developed an impressive following (Bu NP 15:1.1.9), leading the Buddha to declare him the foremost of those who were “impressive all around” (AN 1.213). His song of triumph is recorded at Ud 4.9, while his verses at Thag 10.6 focus on contentment and humility.
sn35.69:1.4: This illustrates the difference between bāhira (“exterior”) and bahiddha (“external, outside”). Bāhira is the outside of an organism or a single thing (such as an altar), whereas bahiddha is something outside a point of reference or removed past a boundary. That is, interior/exterior are two aspects of a single thing, whereas inside/outside are two distinct things.
